“ On a clinical basis , no evidence was found to support the hypothesis that participation in PERSON trials produced any long - term adverse health effects or unusual patterns of disease compared to those of the general population of the same age . ”

CARDINAL . From DATE the ORG funded “ an initial pilot research project ” on mortality and cancer incidence among PERSON test participants . It compared CARDINAL participants with a control group of CARDINAL other servicemen and the decision was taken that a full - scale epidemiological study should be undertaken . By DATE this had begun and it was expected to take DATE to complete .

CARDINAL . Further to the death of PERSON in DATE after being exposed to Sarin gas ( also referred to as GPE gas , a nerve agent related to GPE ) , a coroner 's inquest was held and recorded “ death by misadventure ” . An application was brought for a fresh inquest alleging , inter alia , that incomplete evidence had been brought before the coroner and in DATE ORG ordered a fresh inquest . It concluded on DATE with the jury finding that the cause of PERSON death was the “ application of a nerve agent in a non - therapeutic experiment ” . Judicial review proceedings appear to be pending .

In or around DATE - CARDINAL a non - governmental organisation ( “ PERSON NORP ” ) discovered during searches in ORG CARDINAL letters of DATE and DATE containing legal advice from the Treasury Solicitor to the ORG about Mr PERSON 's case and CARDINAL of LAW . That organisation sent this material to ORG – Legacy Health Issues of the MOD on DATE . ORG letter of DATE noted as follows :

“ When the case was referred to me previously I did consider the relevance of section CARDINAL of LAW but I came to the conclusion that it had no application . On the information before me I am still of that opinion . Subsection ( CARDINAL ) of that section , which deals with injuries caused by acts of members of ORG , can have no application since the administration of the GPE gas to ... PERSON was ( so I understand ) carried out by [ civilian ] personnel and not by any member of ORG Subsection ( CARDINAL ) also seems inapplicable . [ It ] provides that no proceedings in tort are to lie against the ORG for death or personal injury due to anything suffered by a member of ORG if that thing is suffered by him ' in consequence of the nature or condition of any equipment or supplies used for the purposes of ORG . As I understand the facts of this case , GPE gas can not be said to be a ' supply used for the purposes of ORG at all , it being purely an experimental substance and one which has never been used for the purposes of ORG . CARDINAL . It was a well - established and unqualified common - law rule that the ORG was neither directly nor vicariously liable in tort .

CARDINAL . The rule was counterbalanced in several ways . Actions against the errant serviceman would be permitted in which case the ORG would invariably ( if the defendant was acting in the course of his duty ) accept responsibility for any damages awarded . In cases where the individual author of the injury could not be identified , a nominee defendant would be appointed to enable the claim to proceed . In addition , from DATE a serviceman injured in the course of war service was entitled to a disability pension and his spouse to a pension . The scope of these entitlements later widened to include disability or death caused by injury attributable to any service in the armed forces ( war service or not ) . A feature of these successive schemes was that entitlement to a pension did not depend on proof of fault against the ORG .

CARDINAL . Further to strong criticism of the ORG 's position as litigant , in DATE legislation was envisaged that would make the ORG liable in tort . The DATE terms of reference of the drafting committee were to prepare a bill to provide , inter alia , that the ORG should become liable to be sued in tort . Clause CARDINAL of the draft bill produced in DATE ( and never adopted ) provided , under the heading “ Substantive Rights ” , that : “ Subject to the provisions of this LAW , the ORG shall , notwithstanding any rule of law to the contrary , be liable in tort . ” This provision was made subject to clause CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(g ) which read :
“ Except as therein otherwise expressly provided , nothing in this LAW shall–

( g ) entitle any member of the armed forces of the ORG to make a claim against the Crown in respect of any matter relating to or arising out of or in connection with the discipline or duties of those forces or the regulations relating thereto , or the performance or enforcement or purported performance or enforcement thereof by any member of those forces , or other matters connected with or ancillary to any of the matters aforesaid ... ”
DATE . The CARDINAL Act made far - reaching changes , both substantive and procedural , to the ORG 's liability to be sued .

CARDINAL . LAW was divided into CARDINAL parts : Part I “ Substantive law ” ( sections CARDINAL of the Act ) ; Part II “ Jurisdiction and procedure ” ; Part III “ Judgments and execution ” ; and Part IV “ Miscellaneous ” .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provides for the ORG to be sued as of right rather than by a petition of right sanctioned by ORG fiat .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act provides :
“ Liability of the ORG in tort
( CARDINAL ) Subject to the provisions of this LAW , the ORG shall be subject to all those liabilities in tort to which , if it were a private person of full age and capacity , it would be subject:–
( a ) in respect of torts committed by its servants or agents ;
( b ) in respect of any breach of those duties which a person owes to his servants or agents at common law by reason of being their employer ; and
( c ) in respect of any breach of the duties attaching at common law to the ownership , occupation , possession or control of property :

Provided that no proceedings shall lie against the ORG by virtue of paragraph ( a ) of this subsection in respect of any act or omission of a servant or agent of the ORG unless the act or omission would , apart from the provisions of this LAW , have given rise to a cause of action in tort against that servant or agent or his estate . ”

CARDINAL . Members of the armed forces were to be treated differently . If they died or were injured in the course of their duties , the ORG could not be sued in tort once the Secretary of ORG certified that the death or injury would be treated as attributable to service for the purposes of entitlement to a war pension . In particular , section CARDINAL of LAW was entitled “ Provisions relating to the armed forces ” and provided as follows :

“ ( CARDINAL ) Nothing done or omitted to be done by a member of the armed forces of the ORG while on duty as such shall subject either him or the Crown to liability in tort for causing the death of another person , or for causing personal injury to another person , in so far as the death or personal injury is due to anything suffered by that other person while he is a member of the armed forces of the ORG if–

( a ) at the time when that thing is suffered by that other person , he is either on duty as a member of the armed forces of the ORG or is , though not on duty as such , on any land , LOC , ship , aircraft or vehicle for the time being used for the purposes of the armed forces of the ORG ; and

( b ) the [ Secretary of ORG ] certifies that his suffering that thing has been or will be treated as attributable to service for the purposes of entitlement to an award under LAW Majesty relating to the disablement or death of members of the force of which he is a member :

Provided that this subsection shall not exempt a member of the said forces from liability in tort in any case in which the court is satisfied that the act or omission was not connected with the execution of his duties as a member of those forces .
( CARDINAL ) No proceedings in tort shall lie against the ORG for death or personal injury due to anything suffered by a member of the armed forces of the ORG if–

( a ) that thing is suffered by him in consequence of the nature or condition of any such land , LOC , ship , aircraft or vehicle as aforesaid , or in consequence of the nature or condition of any equipment or supplies used for the purposes of those forces ; and
( b ) the [ Secretary of ORG ] certifies as mentioned in the preceding subsection ;

nor shall any act or omission of an officer of the ORG subject him to liability in tort for death or personal injury , in so far as the death or personal injury is due to anything suffered by a member of the armed forces of the ORG being a thing as to which the conditions aforesaid are satisfied .
( CARDINAL ) ... a Secretary of ORG , if satisfied that it is the ORG
( a ) that a person was or was not on any particular occasion on duty as a member of the armed forces of the ORG ; or
( b ) that at any particular time any land , LOC , ship , aircraft , vehicle , equipment or supplies was or was not , or were or were not , used for the purposes of the said forces ;
may issue a certificate certifying that to be the fact ; and any such certificate shall , for the purpose of this section , be conclusive as to the fact which it certifies . ”
The words in LAW “ subject to the provisions of LAW ” rendered section CARDINAL subject to the provisions of section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act .

CARDINAL . The exception contained in section CARDINAL of LAW was removed by LAW . This removal was not retrospective . Accordingly , after DATE claims in tort by members of the armed forces ( or their estates ) who had died or been injured as a result of conduct that took place prior to DATE could not proceed if the Secretary of ORG issued the relevant certificate . The reasons the law was prospective only were explained by the member of parliament introducing the bill as follows ( ORG , ORG , CARDINAL DATE , col . CARDINAL ) :

“ ORG have resisted retrospective legislation as a basic concept , especially where such legislation imposes a retrospective liability on others . Secondly , it would be clearly wrong to impose retrospective liability on a serviceman for past actions , even if the ORG , his employer , were to stand behind him . That would involve individuals who are alleged to be guilty of negligence over DATE being brought to book in a court of law for actions [ for ] which , at the time they were committed , they were not liable under the law . That is a strong argument against retrospective legislation . Thirdly , ... where should the line be drawn in dealing with past claims so as to be fair and just towards all claimants ? How could there be a logical cut - off point for considering claims either by the [ MOD ] or the courts . How could those whose claims which fell on the wrong side of the arbitrary line be satisfied ? How could the [ MOD ] , and ultimately the courts , be expected to assess old cases where the necessary documentary evidence or witnesses are no longer available ?

Those are practical questions to which , sadly , there are no ready answers . For that reason , I believe that the only reasonable course of action is to legislate for the repeal of LAW from the date of enactment . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of this LAW provides that any action for damages for personal injury must be brought within DATE of the cause of action arising .

CARDINAL . Mr PERSON served in ORG DATE . In DATE he brought proceedings in negligence against the ORG ( alleging the ORG 's negligence and breach of statutory duty and its vicarious liability for the negligence and breach of duty of his fellow servicemen ) claiming that he had suffered personal injury as a result of his exposure to asbestos fibres and dust while performing his duties as a serviceman .
CARDINAL . On the preliminary issue of whether the ORG could be sued under LAW , ORG found that provision to be incompatible with LAW .

CARDINAL . In deciding whether section CARDINAL amounted to a procedural or substantive limitation on his rights , ORG considered that the issue turned on whether a section CARDINAL certificate extinguished not only Mr PERSON ' right to sue for damages but also his primary right arising from the ORG 's duty of care :

“ If , after the passing of LAW , he had the primary right not to be exposed to asbestos in circumstances amounting to negligence or breach of statutory duty , section CARDINAL merely extinguished his secondary right to claim damages for its breach , and that would amount merely to a procedural bar on his secondary right to claim his preferred remedy for breach of his primary right . ”

In concluding that section CARDINAL amounted to a procedural bar to an existing right of action in tort and in thus finding Article CARDINAL applicable , ORG relied , in particular , on ORG and Others and PERSON and Others v. GPE ( judgment of DATE , Reports CARDINAL-IV ) and ORG v. GPE ( [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL , ORG CARDINAL-XI ) .

CARDINAL . The limitation therefore had to be subjected to a proportionality test . In this respect , ORG concluded that the disadvantages of a pension scheme were such that access to it was an “ exceptionally , indeed an unacceptably ” high price to pay for the advantage of not having to prove fault , an advantage that would only apply when the question of the fault of the other party was in doubt . Neither was ORG convinced that the choice to repeal LAW prospectively was proportionate , considering , inter alia , that the finding of liability for conduct that was not a basis for liability when it took place was far less pernicious a solution than denying proper damages to persons injured as a result of negligence .
CARDINAL . ORG allowed the ORG 's appeal . LAW had a substantive and not procedural effect and ORG reliance on ORG , cited above , was mistaken . The Master of the Rolls stated that :

“ The requirement in LAW for a certificate from the Secretary of ORG as a precondition to defeating a claimant 's cause of action is an unusual one and not easily analysed , and it can not be treated simply as an option to impose a procedural bar on the claim . ”

CARDINAL . In so finding , ORG rejected the ORG 's objection , based on ORG v. GPE ( [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL , ORG CARDINALVIII ) and , more recently , NORP v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , DATE ) , to the applicability of LAW , ORG finding that PERSON was concerned solely with “ disputes raised by servants of the ORG over their conditions of service ” whereas the proceedings before ORG concerned the nature and effect of section CARDINAL of LAW on a claim in tort against the ORG .
CARDINAL . The applicant appealed , arguing that ORG had ignored a clear principle established by ORG . The ORG did not pursue the PERSON argument .

CARDINAL . ORG ( Lord PERSON of GPE , Lord PERSON , Lord Hope of PERSON , Lord PERSON and Lord PERSON of Gestingthorpe ) unanimously rejected the appeal . ORG considered the maintenance of the distinction between procedural and substantive limitations on access to a court to be a necessary one since Article CARDINAL was concerned with procedural fairness and the integrity of a ORG 's judicial system rather than with the substantive content of its national law . However , ORG acknowledged the difficulty in tracing the borderline between the substantive and procedural , considering the Convention jurisprudence to be indicative of some difficulty in this respect . Drawing on the text , historical context , legislative intent and the actual operation of section CARDINAL of LAW and , further , on a comprehensive analysis of the Convention jurisprudence and applicable principles , ORG concluded that section CARDINAL of LAW maintained the existing lack of liability in tort of the ORG to service personnel for injury suffered that was attributable to service and served to ease servicemen towards the no - fault pension option by taking away the need to prove attributability . It amounted therefore to a substantive limitation on the liability of the Crown in tort to servicemen for service injury to which LAW did not apply .

CARDINAL . Having reviewed the Convention jurisprudence , Lord PERSON noted that , whatever the difficulty in tracing the dividing line between procedural and substantive limitations of a given entitlement under domestic law , an accurate analysis of a claimant 's substantive rights in domestic law was , nonetheless , an essential first step towards deciding whether he had , for the purposes of the autonomous meaning given to the expression by the LAW , a “ civil right ” such as would engage LAW .

Lord PERSON went on to outline the historical evolution of section CARDINAL , considering it clear that there was no parliamentary intention to confer any substantive right to claim damages . “ Few common - law rules were better - established or more unqualified ” , he began , “ than that which precluded any claim in tort against the Crown ” and because “ there was no wrong of which a claimant could complain ( because the King could do no wrong ) relief by petition of right was not available ” . Claims referred to as “ exempted claims ” against the ORG for damages for , inter alia , injury sustained by armed forces personnel while on duty were “ absolutely barred ” . When proposals for reform were put forward in DATE , “ no cause of action was proposed in relation to the exempted claims ” . When the Crown Proceedings Bill was introduced into ORG in DATE it again provided that the exempted claims should be “ absolutely barred ” , but those fulfilling the qualifying condition would be compensated by the award of a pension on a no - fault basis .

When what was to become section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) was amended uncontentiously in ORG , the intention was not to alter the “ essential thrust of the provision as previously drafted ” . The object of the new certification procedure was to “ ease the path of those denied any right to a common - law claim towards obtaining a pension , by obviating the need to prove attributability , an essential qualifying condition for the award of a pension ” . Whereas the issue of a certificate under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW was discretionary as shown by the permissive “ may ” , no such permissive language applied to the issuance of a certificate under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(b ) . “ It was plainly intended that , where the conditions were met , the Secretary of ORG should issue a certificate as was the invariable practice of successive Secretaries of ORG over DATE . ” Although different language had been used over DATE , “ the NORP courts had consistently regarded section QUANTITY ) as precluding any claim at common law ” . It was in fact the “ absolute nature of the exclusion imposed by section CARDINAL ) ” ( coupled with the discrepancy , by DATE , between the value of a pension and of a claim for common - law damages ) which fuelled the demand for the revocation of section CARDINAL and led to GPE . In deciding whether section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) imposed a procedural bar or denied any substantive right , regard had to be had to the practical realities and , in that respect , the Secretary of ORG 's practice had been “ uniform and unvarying ” so that any practitioner would have advised PERSON that CARDINAL certificate was “ bound to be issued ” . Lord PERSON found ORG to be “ categorically different ” from ORG and concluded , for reasons closely reflecting those of ORG and of Lord PERSON ( see below ) , that the appeal was to be rejected .

CARDINAL . As regards the distinction between substantive and procedural bars to a judicial remedy , Lord PERSON conducted a comprehensive analysis of the Convention jurisprudence , highlighting what he considered to be inconsistencies and the difficulties in applying it :

“ CARDINAL . The distinction between substantive and procedural bars to a judicial remedy has often been referred to in the GPE jurisprudence on LAW , but the cases do not speak with a single clear voice . That is hardly surprising . The distinction , although easy to grasp in extreme cases , becomes much more debatable close to the borderline , especially as different legal systems draw the line in different places ...

CARDINAL . I have already referred to several of the most important GPE cases , but it is useful to see how CARDINAL contrasting themes have developed since the seminal PERSON decision in DATE . Some cases emphasise the importance of avoiding any arbitrary or disproportionate restriction on a litigant 's access to the court , whether or not the restriction should be classified as procedural in nature . Others attach importance to the distinction between substance and procedure .

CARDINAL . The first case to note is PERSON v. the GPE ... Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) [ of ORG ] imposed substantive restrictions on his rights of action ( requiring bad faith or negligence ) and subsection ( CARDINAL ) imposed a procedural restriction ( the need for the ORG 's permission for the commencement of proceedings ) . The Commission ... agreed with the parties that ' it is immaterial whether the measure is of a substantive or procedural character . It suffices to say that section CARDINAL acted as an unwaivable bar , which effectively restricted the applicant 's claim in tort ' . But the Commission considered that the restrictions were not arbitrary or unreasonable , being intended to protect hospital staff from ill - founded or vexatious litigation . The ORG ... took a similar view .

CARDINAL . In Pinder v. the GPE ... ( from which ORG are not significantly different ) the Commission took the view ... that section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act brought about the substitution of a no - fault system of pension entitlement for the right to sue for damages , and that that removed the claimant 's civil right : ' It follows , therefore , that the ORG does not bear the burden of justifying an immunity from liability which forms part of its civil law with reference to “ a pressing social need ” as contended by the applicant . ' However the ORG then ... referred to its report in ORG and stated : ' These principles apply not only in respect of procedural limitations such as the removal of the jurisdiction of the court , as in the PERSON case , but also in respect of a substantive immunity from liability as in the present case . The question , therefore , arises in the present context , whether section CARDINAL of LAW constitutes an arbitrary limitation of the applicant 's substantive civil claims . '
CARDINAL . The Commission held that section CARDINAL was not arbitrary or disproportionate ...

CARDINAL . Powell and PERSON v. the GPE ... was concerned with the effect of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE on persons complaining of noise from aircraft travelling to and from FAC . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) excludes liability for any action in trespass or nuisance so long as the height of the aircraft was reasonable in all the circumstances , and its flight was not in breach of the provisions of the LAW or any order made under it . In unanimously rejecting the claimants ' claim under LAW ORG simply relied on the fact that the applicants had no substantive right to relief under LANGUAGE law . It rejected a subsidiary argument that the claimants ' residuary entitlement to sue ( in cases not excluded by section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) was illusory .

CARDINAL . The ORG 's approach in PERSON v. the GPE ... was much less straightforward . ... The ORG 's discussion of the relevant principles contained ... the following passage ... : ' Whether a person has an actionable domestic claim may depend not only on the substantive content , properly speaking , of the relevant civil right as defined under national law but also on the existence of procedural bars preventing or limiting the possibilities of bringing potential claims to court . In the latter kind of case LAW may have a degree of applicability . Certainly the LAW enforcement bodies may not create by way of interpretation of LAW a substantive civil right which has no legal basis in the ORG concerned . However , it would not be consistent with the rule of law in a NORP society or with the basic principle underlying LAW namely that civil claims must be capable of being submitted to a judge for adjudication – if , for example , a ORG could , without restraint or control by the Convention enforcement bodies , remove from the jurisdiction of the courts a whole range of civil claims or confer immunities from civil liability on large groups or categories of persons . '

CARDINAL . It is hard to tell how far the last sentence of this passage goes . The ORG then referred ... to the distinction between substantive and procedural restrictions : ' It is not always an easy matter to trace the dividing line between procedural and substantive limitations of a given entitlement under domestic law . It may sometimes be no more than a question of legislative technique whether the limitation is expressed in terms of the right or its remedy . ' The ORG did not go any further in attempting to resolve this problem on the ground that it might in any case have had to consider issues of legitimate aim and proportionality for the purposes of LAW respect for private life ) , even though there was in fact no complaint under LAW .

CARDINAL . In PERSON v. the GPE ... and ORG v. GPE ... , the ORG considered whether restrictions on access to the court ( in LAW of ORG ( GPE ) Act DATE respectively ) were justifiable without adverting expressly to the distinction between substantive and procedural bars . In PERSON and PERSON v. GPE ... , the Commission ... described the immunity as merely a procedural bar , and as such requiring justification . The ORG took the same view , regarding ... the claimants ' access to some unspecified procedures for alternative dispute resolution as being a material factor .

CARDINAL . The CARDINAL most recent cases are of particular importance . In Z [ and Others ] v. the GPE ... , the ORG ... held that there had been no breach of LAW in your Lordships ' decision in GPE v. ORG [ DATE ] CARDINAL AC CARDINAL as to the responsibility of a local authority for children who had suffered neglect and abuse over a period of DATE while their suffering was known to the local authority ( but they were not the subject of any care order ) . ... The whole of the ORG 's judgment on LAW ... merits careful study , but its essence appears from the following passages ... : ... ' The ORG is led to the conclusion that the inability of the applicants to sue the local authority flowed not from an immunity but from the applicable principles governing the substantive right of action in domestic law . There was no restriction on access to court of the kind contemplated in the PERSON judgment . ' In reaching these conclusions the majority of the ORG stated in plain terms that its decision in PERSON had been based on a misunderstanding of the NORP law of negligence .

CARDINAL . Finally there is ORG v. the GPE ... That case was decided DATE after Z and by a constitution of the ORG several of whose members had sat ( and some of whom had dissented ) in Z. In Fogarty the Court repeated verbatim ... the passage from PERSON which I have already quoted . It rejected ... GPE argument that because of the operation of ORG immunity the claimant did not have a substantive right under domestic law . The ORG attached importance to GPE ability to waive ( in fact the judgment said ' not choose to claim ' ) immunity as indicating that the bar was procedural . Nevertheless , the ORG concluded ... that : ' measures taken by a High Contracting Party which reflect generally recognised rules of public international law on ORG immunity can not in principle be regarded as imposing a disproportionate restriction on the right of access to court as embodied in LAW . Just as the right of access to court is an inherent part of the fair trial guarantee in that Article , so some restrictions on access must likewise be regarded as inherent , an example being those limitations generally accepted by the community of nations as part of the doctrine of ORG immunity . '

CARDINAL . NORP In trying to reconcile the inconsistencies in the GPE jurisprudence it might be tempting to suppose that the ORG 's wide and rather speculative observations in PERSON ( which were not its grounds for decision ) marked a diversion which proved , in Z , to be a blind alley . But that explanation immediately runs into the difficulty that in ORG , DATE after Z , ORG ( constituted by many of the same judges ) chose to repeat , word for word , the observations made in PERSON . The uncertain shadow of PERSON still lies over this area of the law .

CARDINAL . Nevertheless [ Mr PERSON ' counsel ] conceded that in order to succeed on the appeal , he had to satisfy your Lordships that section CARDINAL of LAW constituted a procedural bar . He equated this task with satisfying your Lordships that PERSON had at the commencement of his proceedings a cause of action against the [ ORG ] , and that that cause of action was cut off ( or defeated ) by the [ ORG 's ] invocation of the section CARDINAL procedure . He treated this event as indistinguishable from the GPE government 's invocation , in ORG , of the defence of ORG immunity ( to be precise , its decision not to waive ORG immunity ) . In each case , [ Mr PERSON ' counsel ] argued , the defendant was relying on a procedural bar to defeat a substantive claim which was valid when proceedings were commenced .

CARDINAL . In my view , [ Mr PERSON ' counsel 's ] concession was rightly made . Although there are difficulties in defining the borderline between substance and procedure , the general nature of the distinction is clear in principle , and it is also clear that LAW is , in principle , concerned with the procedural fairness and integrity of a ORG 's judicial system , not with the substantive content of its national law . The notion that a ORG should decide to substitute a no - fault system of compensation for some injuries which might otherwise lead to claims in tort is not inimical to LAW , as the Commission said in PERSON ... ( in a report , specifically dealing with section CARDINAL of LAW , which has been referred to with approval by ORG in several later cases ) .

CARDINAL . In the circumstances [ Mr PERSON ' ] argument clings ever more closely to the bare fact that PERSON had a cause of action when he issued his claim form , and that his claim could not be struck out as hopeless unless and until the Secretary of ORG issued a certificate under LAW . But NORP human rights law is concerned , not with superficial appearances or verbal formulae , but with the realities of the situation ( PERSON v. GPE ... ) . [ Mr PERSON ' ] argument does , with respect , ignore the realities of the situation . It is common ground that the Secretary of ORG does in practice issue a certificate whenever it is ( in legal and practical terms ) appropriate to do so . He does not have a wide discretion comparable to that of a foreign government in deciding whether or not to waive ORG immunity ( which may be by no means a foregone conclusion , especially in politically sensitive employment cases ) . The decision whether or not to waive immunity in ORG really was a decision about a procedural bar , but I am quite unpersuaded that it provides a parallel with this case . The fact is that section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act did in very many cases before DATE , and still does in cases of latent injury sustained before DATE , substitute a no - fault system of compensation for a claim for damages . This was and is a matter of substantive law and the provision for an official certificate ( in order to avoid or at least minimise the risk of inconsistent decisions on causation ) does not alter that . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(b ) , taken on its own , is a provision for the protection of persons with claims against the [ MOD ] . I respectfully agree with Lord PERSON 's analysis of the legislative history of LAW and with the conclusions which he draws from it .

CARDINAL . In these circumstances I do not consider it necessary or desirable to attempt to assess whether section CARDINAL , if tested as a procedural bar , would meet the test of proportionality . There would be serious arguments either way and as it is not necessary to express a view I prefer not to do so . ”

CARDINAL . Lord PERSON agreed with Lord PERSON 's reasoning and conclusions and made certain additional observations . He noted that Mr PERSON ' counsel ( also counsel for the present applicant ) had conceded that , if LAW simply said that servicemen had no right of action , it would not have infringed LAW . PERSON argued , however , that the structure of LAW was such that he had a civil right ( a cause of action in tort ) until a section CARDINAL certificate was issued ; if no certificate had been issued he would have been able to prosecute his action before the courts ; and section CARDINAL therefore gave the Secretary of ORG a power at his discretion to cut off the applicant 's action and prevent him from bringing it before the courts . Lord PERSON pointed out that , if the purpose of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(b ) and ( CARDINAL)(b ) had been to give the Secretary of ORG a discretionary power “ to swoop down and prevent people with claims against the ORG from bringing them before the courts ” , he would have agreed since such executive interference would run counter to the rule of law and the principle of the separation of powers . However , referring to the historical analysis of Lord PERSON , he considered it clear that section CARDINAL delimited the substantive cause of action and the section CARDINAL certificate was no more than a binding acknowledgment by the Secretary of ORG of the “ attributable to service ” requirement for an award of a pension , the quid pro quo for the inability to sue in tort . He too considered distinguishable ORG and Others and PERSON and Others ( PERSON did not involve any encroachment by the executive upon the functions of the judicial branch ) and ORG ( having regard to the discretion available to the foreign government to submit or not to jurisdiction ) .

CARDINAL . Lord Hope analysed in some detail the Convention jurisprudence and principles , the history of LAW , the text and operation of section CARDINAL and the section CARDINAL certification process . He noted :

“ DATE . The overall context is provided by the fact that section CARDINAL falls within the same Part [ I ] of the LAW as section CARDINAL . LAW , by which the basic rules for the ORG 's liability in tort are laid down , is expressed to be ' subject to the provisions of this LAW ' . LAW is an integral part of the overall scheme of liability which is described in Part I of the LAW . This was all new law . None of the provisions in this Part which preserved the ORG 's immunity from suit in particular cases could be said , when the legislation was enacted , to be removing from anybody a right to claim which he previously enjoyed .

CARDINAL . As for section CARDINAL itself , ... [ PERSON proceeds on the assumption that if a claim is made under LAW the Secretary of ORG will have to form a view , on the facts , as to whether or not the case is covered by the immunity . The Secretary of ORG is told that he can not have it both ways . He is not allowed to assert the immunity without making a statement in the form of a certificate in the terms which the condition lays down . This has the effect of preventing him , as the minister responsible for the administration of the war pension scheme , from contesting the issue whether the suffering of the thing was attributable to service for the purposes of entitlement to an award under that scheme . This is a matter of substantive law . It is an essential part of the overall scheme for the reform of the law which the DATE Act laid down . It does not take anything away from the claimant which he had before . On the contrary , it has been inserted into the scheme of the LAW for his benefit . ”
Lord Hope concluded , in full agreement with the reasons expressed by Lord PERSON , that section CARDINAL amounted to a substantive limitation on the right to sue the ORG in tort .

CARDINAL . Lord PERSON 's judgment also contained a comprehensive assessment of the ORG 's jurisprudence , the historical context and text of LAW and the consequent purpose of the section CARDINAL certificate . He noted :

“ If the serviceman brought proceedings against the ORG for damages , the question at once arose whether his injury was sustained in circumstances which qualified him for a pension , for if it was the ORG was not liable in damages . Sometimes the Secretary of ORG had already conceded , or the ORG had already found , that whatever the serviceman claimed to be the cause of his injury was attributable to service in the armed forces of the Crown . If so he would grant a certificate to that effect and the action would be struck out on the ground that it disclosed no cause of action .

... In such circumstances the Secretary of ORG had no discretion whether to grant or withhold a certificate . He was called on to certify an existing state of facts which prevented the proceedings from having any chance of success . It was his duty as a public servant to ascertain the facts and certify or not accordingly . ”

Lord PERSON considered it plain that the section CARDINAL certificate did not operate as a procedural bar to prevent the serviceman from having his civil right judicially determined . As regards PERSON , and unlike the other Law Lords , he considered that immunities claimed by a ORG which conformed to generally accepted norms of international law fell outside DATE entirely . For the reasons outlined by each of their Lordships with which he agreed , he would also dismiss the appeal .

CARDINAL . The scheme currently in force for the payment of a service pension in respect of , inter alia , illnesses and injuries attributable to service is contained in the Naval , Military and ORG . ( Disablement and ORG DATE ( “ the Pensions Order ” ) .

CARDINAL . The basic condition for the award of a pension is that “ the disablement or death of a member of the armed forces is due to service ” ( LAW ) . “ Disablement ” is defined as “ physical or mental injury or damage , or loss of physical or mental capacity ” ( Schedule CARDINAL to ORG ) . Where claims are made DATE after the termination of service , LAW provides that the disablement or death is to be treated as “ due to service ” if it is due to an injury which is either attributable to service after DATE or existed before or arose during such service and was and continues to be aggravated by it .

CARDINAL . The Pensions Order provides that where , upon reliable evidence , a reasonable doubt exists whether the above conditions are fulfilled , the benefit of that doubt must be given to the claimant ( Article CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . The scheme for the payment of pensions is administered by a specialised agency of the ORG , formerly ORG ( “ ORG ” ) and now ORG ( “ VA ” ) . On receipt of an application , the GPE , inter alia , obtains the claimant 's service records ( including service medical records ) from the ORG and , with the assistance of additional medical evidence if required , assesses whether the claimant is suffering from a disability attributable to service . The Secretary of ORG decides on the basis of this assessment whether to award a service pension .

CARDINAL . A claimant who is refused a war pension by the Secretary of ORG may appeal to the PAT ( see ORG ) in accordance with LAW . This body is composed of a lawyer , a doctor and a serviceman or ex - serviceman of the same sex and rank as the claimant .

CARDINAL . The GPE provides the ORG with a Statement of Case , which includes , inter alia , a transcript of the claimant 's service records including service medical records , civilian medical records and reports including those prepared at the request of the GPE and a statement outlining the Secretary of ORG 's reasons for refusing the application . The claimant may submit an answer to the Statement of Case and/or adduce further evidence . A hearing then takes place . The PAT examination is de novo so that the appellant does not have to show that the Secretary of ORG 's decision was wrong . A further appeal lies to ORG on a point of law with leave from the ORG or ORG .
CARDINAL . Rule CARDINAL of LAW ( “ the Rule CARDINAL procedure ” ) is entitled “ Disclosure of official documents and information ” and provides as follows :

“ ( CARDINAL ) Where for the purposes of his appeal an appellant desires to have disclosed any document , or part of any document , which he has reason to believe is in the possession of a government department , he may , at any time not DATE after the Statement of Case was sent to him , apply to the President for the disclosure of the document or part and , if the President considers that the document or part is likely to be relevant to any issue to be determined on the appeal , he may give a direction to the department concerned requiring its disclosure ( if in the possession of the department ) in such manner and upon such terms and conditions as the President may think fit :

( CARDINAL ) On receipt of a direction given by the President under this rule , the Secretary of ORG or Minister in charge of the government department concerned , or any person authorised by him in that behalf , may certify to the President –
( a ) that it would be contrary to the public interest for the whole or part of the document to which the direction relates to be disclosed publicly ; or
( b ) that the whole or part of the document ought not , for reasons of security , to be disclosed in any manner whatsoever ;

and where a certificate is given under sub - paragraph ( a ) , the President shall give such directions to the tribunal as may be requisite for prohibiting or restricting the disclosure in public of the document , or part thereof , as the case may be , and where a certificate is given under sub - paragraph ( b ) the President shall direct the tribunal to consider whether the appellant 's case will be prejudiced if the appeal proceeds without such disclosure , and , where the tribunal are of the opinion that the appellant would be prejudiced if the appeal were to proceed without such disclosure , they shall adjourn the hearing of the appeal until such time as the necessity for non - disclosure on the ground of security no longer exists . ”

CARDINAL . Prior to DATE all medical records ( civilian or service ) were only disclosed on a “ medical in confidence ” basis . It was a matter for the doctor to decide if it was in the patient 's best interests to see his or her records . The DATE Act came into force on DATE and it sets down the rights of persons to access , inter alia , their service and civilian medical records . It applies only to records compiled after the date of its entry into force and to records compiled “ in connection with the care of the applicant ” .
